Hi Curran,

What can I do to provide better photos? What angles
and such? I'll also make precise measurments.
A polish would bring out the hamon much clearer, I had
one local collector look at it and he felt that it was
Koto period and also cut down as you stated. Blade
light and superbly balanced...feels like an extension
of your hand.

Thanks
Verne

--- Curran Campbell <neobliviscar@...> wrote:
> Verne,
> 
>    I cannot tell a lot from your sword photos. I
> wish
> someone more experienced would step in and comment,
> as
> I don't think I am very qualified with less than 5
> years experience. Take my comments just as a
> beginning
> point and allow for the fact that others may feel I
> am
> absolutely wrong.
> 
> The kissaki looks chu to ko-kissaki and front part
> tapers quickly. What is the length of the cutting
> edge? 
>    Tobiyaki (if correct term) is associated with
> So-Den. My feeling off the sword is that it is
> Shinto
> and hastily shortened for WW2 mounts. Out of polish,
> unsigned, and just photos....very hard for me to
> tell.
>     I may be entirely misreading the blade, but am
> operating under the belief that few if any WWII
> smiths
> executed tobiyaki. I do not know which Shinto or
> Shinshinto schools did.
> 
> Curran
> 
> --- Verne Turpin <ren47@...> wrote:
> > I will add a couple of more photos showing the
> > kissaki
> > and whole blade.
> > Thanks
> > --- Curran Campbell <neobliviscar@...>
> wrote:
> > > Vern & Robert,
> > > 
> > > I figured someone would comment with more
> > knowledge
> > > than me. But I'll try and further discussion on
> > it.
> > > Those with more knowledge ___PLEASE___correct
> me.
> > > 
> > > Very -off the cuff- impression is it was later
> > > Shinto
> > > or Shinshinto shortened to fit WW II mounts.
> > Little
> > > guess as to school. I have much to learn about
> > > ShinShinto.
> > >   I don't know much either about WWII mounts, so
> > not
> > > sure how much that would trim. Would move the
> > machi
> > > up
> > > considerably and leave a bright nakago mune
> > behind?
> > > Does seem to my eye to have tobiyaki, so I
> thought
> > > that was a good sign.
> > >    I wondered about the geometry on the kissaki
> > and
> > > would like to see the sugata/shape of the whole
> > > sword.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Curran
> > > 
> > > --- Robert Gilmore <rgilmore82@...>
> > wrote:
> > > > Does anyone have any comments on Verne's
> sword? 
> > > > Admittedly it is 
> > > > difficult to see the hamon in his photos, but
> he
> > > is
> > > > describing 
> > > > Tobiyaki.  Also, it is interesting to see how
> > the
> > > > nakago mune is shiny 
> > > > near the machi.  I haven't seen this before. 
> > > Would
> > > > this indicate a 
> > > > recent  machi repair, or a tight habaki that
> is
> > > > burnishing the nakago?
> > > > 
> > > > Bob
> > > > Verne wrote:
> > > > 
> > > > >Hello for Florida, Just joined and am fairly
> > new
> > > to
> > > > japanese sword 
> > > > >collecting. I have created an album under
> Verne
> > > and
> > > > they are pics of 
> > > > >a sword I just found at an antique shop.Would
> > > like
> > > > some opinons, not 
> > > > >signed. Could be a shorted katana bordering
> on
> > > > wakasashi length. The 
> > > > >sword had just been brought in by a WW2 vet's
> > > widow
> > > > of which he will 
> > > > >give me her name to verify the story.I need
> > help
> > > on
> > > > identifying the 
> > > > >hamo, it is active and on both side there are
> a
> > > > couple of pea shaped 
> > > > >temper spots floating over the main temper.
> > > > >Thanks
> > > > >Verne
> > > > >
